ad_efficiency.formula: ROAS = Shopify revenue attributed / Meta spend

revenue.definition: Shopify gross sales (total_price from paid orders — includes shipping + tax, after discounts, before refunds). NOT GA4 revenue.
revenue.note: All paid orders are paginated — revenue and AOV are exact, not sampled

sessions.definition: GA4 sessions from the last 30 days

conversion_rate.warning: Cross-source metric — directional only. Do NOT present as exact.

roas.warning: NOT Meta's self-reported ROAS. Uses Shopify revenue as the source of truth.

ad_conversions.note: Meta's attribution is generous. Always cross-reference with Shopify.

discrepancy_flag.rule: Meta accounts for ~40% of orders. Only flag if Meta-reported purchases drop significantly below the expected 40% share of Shopify orders (i.e. below 20% share), suggesting tracking or attribution issues.

data_source_notes.ga4_sessions: Shopify reports higher session counts than GA4 due to Google Signals thresholding, cookie consent, and ad blockers. GA4 sessions are used for conversion rate calculations but are likely undercounted.
data_source_notes.revenue_source_of_truth: Shopify gross sales (total_price from paid orders) are the revenue source of truth. GA4 revenue is NOT used.
data_source_notes.multi_channel: Meta Ads accounts for ~40% of orders. Remaining 60% comes from TikTok, email, organic, and direct. Do not expect Meta purchases to match total Shopify orders.
data_source_notes.order_pagination: All paid orders are paginated from the Shopify REST API — revenue and AOV are exact totals, not sampled from 250 orders.

session_drop_flag.rule: Flag if sessions drop more than 40% day-over-day — likely a tracking issue, not a real traffic drop

revenue_gap_flag.rule: Flag if GA4 revenue and Shopify revenue differ by more than 20% — data integrity issue

minimum_purchases.rule: Do not draw conclusions about conversion rates or product performance with fewer than 30 purchases

minimum_trend_days.rule: Do not call something a trend with fewer than 7 days of data
